page.title: 20The River Brue
page.content: The River Brue is very important to the Somerset Levels because the amount of peat here makes the ground very boggy after heavy rainfall. A system of drainage ditches or rhynes leads from the Brue which has to be cleaned out every autumn because of the large amount of weed etc which collects. A recent dip into the river where it is joined by the Mill Stream revealed a wide selection of water life including common reed, duckweed, tubifex, water spiders, water boatmen, upside-down boatmen, water snails, water scorpions, pond skaters, water beetle larvae and swan mussels. The river is sometimes used for fund raising events like the Baltonsborough Splash which takes place annually. Home made rafts are raced from Wallyer's Bridge to the weir.
